0.text:
What determines CS:GO’s loading times? I
sat through over 150 loading screens to find

1.text:
to know for this video. For most of these
tests, I loaded the game up and ran the dust2

6.text:
loading screen 3 times in a row. This way
I get to see if the first loading time is

10.text:
different from the others. I would then repeat
this 3 times to show the variance in the results.

16.text:
On highest graphical settings, it takes around
19 seconds to load Dust2 for the first time

20.text:
and about 17 seconds after that. On lowest,
it’s slightly faster again with the first

25.text:
loading screen taking between about 16 and
18 seconds and ones after that between 14

30.text:
and 15. I aim to speed this up as much as
I can.

33.text:
But firstly, let’s try slowing it down more.
We all like RAM. Can’t get enough of the

38.text:
stuff. I have 16 GB normally, so I took out
some so I was left with 8. And loading times

44.text:
increased! Not by much- about half a second
on average, but still a bit of a difference.

49.text:
On low settings, there wasn’t any difference
to be seen. So I lowered my PC down to just

54.text:
4, which is the minimum that anybody should
have in this day and age. On high settings,

58.text:
the first loading screen after starting Counter
Strike took an additional 3 seconds. The second

63.text:
or third time I loaded Dust2 also took longer
but only by about a second or so. On low settings,

68.text:
the results were still the same. If you play
on low settings, you can get away with just

73.text:
4 GB of RAM. If not, then the more the merrier.
Back to 16 GB of RAM for the rest of this

78.text:
video, but there’s one more thing I need
to mention: there’s a difference between

82.text:
reloading Counter Strike from the desktop
and rebooting the computer and loading it.

86.text:
And I’m sorry to say that, to make my life
easier, I tried to avoid including this very

90.text:
first loading screen after a system boot in
these tests, but I can briefly summarise what

94.text:
sort of a difference it makes. With an SSD,
the VERY first load after starting your PC

99.text:
takes an extra 3 to 4 seconds. But with a
hard drive, it effectively DOUBLES this very

104.text:
first loading time.
That’s right- I tested on a hard drive as

107.text:
well. And I was pleasantly surprised! Because
aside from this massively long first loading

112.text:
time, future loading screens were actually
faster than from my SSD. And this happened

116.text:
almost every time, both on high and low graphics
settings!

120.text:
Now remember, my Steam and operating system
were still on an SSD and Counter Strike had

124.text:
the whole hard drive to itself, so it’s
probably faster than if you’re running everything

128.text:
from the same hard drive. But it makes me
wonder if you could speed it up further by

131.text:
having two SSDs, with Counter Strike having
one to itself. If you want to try that then

136.text:
please, do! I won’t bother.
Let’s test the age-old question: does pressing

141.text:
buttons while the computer’s loading slow
it down? I alternated between sitting patiently

145.text:
and pretending to play deathmatch frantically
and I’m happy -but somehow also disappointed-

150.text:
to say that it made no difference to how long
it took to load.

153.text:
The same couldn’t be said for the console
being open, though. It automatically closes

157.text:
when you load a level, but if you quickly
press it again it’ll show up and it made

161.text:
it take 50% longer to load! Don’t have the
console up.

165.text:
And next up, fps_max. By default it’s set
to 300. But what if we raise it to 1000?!

172.text:
Shock, horror, it made the time shoot up to
30 SECONDS- the longest in this video! On

177.text:
the other hand, if you lower fps_max to 59,
which is the lowest it can go, loading screens

182.text:
go down to under 11 seconds! This one console
command is very powerful and shows just how

187.text:
broken Global Offensive is Valve please fix.
I blame THIS bit of the loading screen, where

192.text:
the background image fades into view. This
takes a lot longer if the framerate is higher.

197.text:
I don’t care why. It simply shouldn’t.
I also tried fullscreen, fullscreen windowed

202.text:
and windowed to see if that made any difference
but it didn’t. But bear in mind that this

206.text:
was tested on Windows 7! Since loading screens
aren’t boring enough for me, I then downloaded

212.text:
and upgraded to Windows 10. And loading times
increased by 2-3 seconds, both on low and

217.text:
high graphics settings! This isn’t good!
HOWEVER, on Windows 10 if you set it to windowed

223.text:
or fullscreen windowed, the loading times
end up being a second faster than on Windows

227.text:
7 on high settings, and a staggering 5 seconds
faster on low! It’s here that I saw my first

232.text:
sub-10 second loading time, using low settings
on Windows 10 in windowed mode.

237.text:
And they dropped by a further 2 seconds once
I lowered my fps_max to 59. And this was where

242.text:
I got my lowest time. Just 7.38 seconds to
load Dust2. But only once it had already been

249.text:
loaded.
But what about if it was on a hard drive as

251.text:
well?!?! Sadly, it didn’t work this time
and actually took a little bit longer. But

256.text:
I’m happy. I’ve managed to shave 10 seconds
off my original loading times, all through

260.text:
simple, EZ console commands and options. I’m
sure there are plenty of other things I could

265.text:
have tried but unfortunately, the excitement
of watching the loading screens got too much

269.text:
for me and I had to end it here. So, as always,
Valve, pls fix.
